awd_titl_txt: Acoustics-based Structural Health Monitoring of Closed-Cavities and Its Application to Wind Turbine Blades
awd_abstract_narration:
Wind turbines operate under extreme loads and suffer from reliability issues attributed to manufacturing defects, fatigue, or extreme weather conditions. Blades are one of the most critical and vulnerable parts of modern wind turbines and are subject to blade edge splits, holes, or cracks that can lead to failures that can be catastrophic. In order to help identify damage in wind turbine blades, several approaches have been used in the wind industry, most of which require transducers to be mounted on the turbine blades, have not been effective, or require visual inspection. This award supports the fundamental research needed to understand the influence of damage on the acoustic radiation from and through the turbine blades to enable an efficient health monitoring framework. A significant outcome of this research is to improve the reliability of wind energy harvesting turbines thereby lowering energy costs, making their use more globally widespread, resulting in a reduction of greenhouse gases that will help to retard climate change. As part of this project, the UML team will collaborate with the KidWind Project to impact K-12 students who constitute the next generation of scientists and engineers. These outreach efforts will be delivered in collaboration with a team of middle and high school teachers motivating women, and underrepresented minority groups to become interested in science and engineering, while at the same time educating the general public. 

This project will generate scientific knowledge advancing acoustic interrogation techniques, allowing them to be implemented for operational damage detection and identification. The research will achieve a fundamental understanding of the influence of damage severity and location on acoustic radiation from cavity structures. The causal relationship of both controlled deterministic and naturally excited aerodynamic sources of sound on acoustic cavity radiation and response will be investigated. The sensitivity of several detection and identification techniques for different damage types, geometries, locations, frequency ranges, and severity levels will be assessed and quantified. A variety of empirical and computational investigations will be made to investigate the influence of damage on source-path-receiver dynamics of cavity structures. An understanding of the influence of acoustic source and sensor placement within a cavity will help to minimize the instrumentation required while achieving maximum damage detection capability.

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled a complete understanding of the impact of structural damage on the acoustic radiation from cavity structures (such as wind turbine blades) excited by acoustic sources (such as wind noise). The investigation on the fundamental mechanisms of acoustic radiation from cavity structures with modified acoustic transmission through their boundaries when they inhibit damage led to a novel operational sensing, monitoring and structural damage detection technique. Although a variety of structural health monitoring technologies do exist and can perform well in a laboratory setting, they are generally not well suited for monitoring in the field under realistic conditions. The sensing technologies have not been adopted largely because of their limited damage detection range requiring a significant number of sensors to cover a large area of interest, cost, or effectiveness. This transformative research has two complementary components (active and passive acoustic sensing for damage detection and identification) that achieved an understanding of how perturbations in the underlying aeroacoustic dynamic response and transmission loss in cavity structures for different operating conditions relate to structural damage. The project employed a synergistic combination of computational modeling and experimental validation studies at small and large scales to provide a fundamental scientific understanding necessary to enable in-situ damage identification using acoustic signatures. In line with the project goals, below list would constitute the most important achievements of this project:

(i)     This project enabled team to develop a novel acoustics-based structural health monitoring approach for dynamic cavity structures. Dynamic cavity structures include wind turbine blades, automobile/aircraft/rotorcraft cabins as well as underwater and airborne vehicles and objects.

(ii)   The team has developed a novel acoustic sensing system that continuously listen and interrogate cavity structures to detect and identify damage during their operation.

(iii) Over the duration of this project, the project team has conducted data collection at the Wind Technology Testing Center in Charlestown, MA during wind turbine blade fatigue testing. The team implemented the novel acoustic sensing/monitoring system into a few ~50m-60m blades and collected acoustic information. The team has identified trends between an incipient damage and the acoustic data. Trends between strain and acoustic data collected from the same blade were also identified and used for identifying damage.

(iv)  The team collaborated with Pattern Energy to conduct field tests in a wind farm (Sweetwater 2, TX). These tests were performed on a utility-scale turbine in a wind farm selected by Pattern Energy based upon their experience. The turbine that was selected for conducting these tests have some prior damage on one of the blades, whereas the other two blades were healthy with no damage. The acoustic sensing system developed, designed and procured by the project team was installed by working with the personnel from Pattern Energy. The field tests enabled the team to make measurements and record data over several turbine operating conditions. This was the first time an acoustic sensing based in-blade monitoring system was ever developed and implemented on a utility-scale wind turbine in operation.

(v)    Signal processing and machine learning techniques have been developed and verified to successfully identify damage cases.

(vi)  The computational modeling effort under this project has primarily focused on studying and developing fast numerical techniques that could aid in the analysis and development of active/passive acoustic damage detection systems for wind turbines. This enabled development of a lumped parameter acoustic modeling approach to predict noise generated by flow over undamaged blade sections as well as blades with damage. The team has also developed a high-frequency acoustic simulation approach for blades with damage using a ray-tracing based methodology.

(vii)            Some of the findings have been benchmarked with wind tunnel flow experiments including the sensitivity of the passive damage detection approach for varying levels of damage and external air flow for cavity structures (box and blade section were used). A number of wind tunnel tests and data processing to improve computational aeroacoustics model development and validation.

(viii)          The project has enabled the training and education for 2 graduate level students working directly on this project. The project has also made it possible to train and educate several undergraduate and high school students through internships and summer schools.

(ix)  The project enabled development of an educational module. More specifically, the project team in collaborations with KidWind has developed a wind turbine acoustics module to train K2-12 students. This will help disseminate information on wind turbines, energy generation, acoustics and dynamic systems at various levels and venues at the K-12 levels. Outcomes of the project have been presented at conferences, and also been published in high-impact journal papers to educate public including students, researchers, engineers and scientists.
